Award.AwardTitle: Regulation of the Actin Cytoskeleton by Prostaglandin Signaling

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
Prostaglandins are emerging as key lipid signals that regulate actin cytoskeletal remodeling. There are five well-characterized types of prostaglandins, each initiating one or more signaling cascades, and modulating actin dynamics in a cell-type specific manner. Actin is the most abundant protein in cells and generates polarized filaments that are further organized into a variety of structures to mediate basic biological functions such as cell shape, adhesion, division, and migration. Such remodeling, or rearrangement, of the actin cytoskeleton is mediated by the coordinated efforts of greater than 100 known actin binding proteins, and is tightly regulated by numerous signaling pathways. While it is clear that prostaglandins are signals that regulate actin remodeling, how they do so is poorly understood. To elucidate the molecular mechanisms utilized by prostaglandins to regulate actin dynamics in vivo, Drosophila oogenesis was established as a new model for studying prostaglandin signaling. Both pharmacologic and genetic perturbations of prostaglandin signaling result in the loss of the actin structures necessary for the contractile process by which the cytoplasmic contents of the support or nurse cells are dumped into the oocyte. The project exploits Drosophila's short generation time, the use of a non-essential adult tissue, the well-characterized process of nurse cell dumping, available genetic mutations in genes encoding cytoskeletal regulators, and the ability to perform pharmacologic and live-imaging studies on cultured follicles (eggs). Using this follicle maturation system, the mechanism by which signaling by two prostaglandins regulates actin dynamics in a normal, physiological context - where cells must interact with and respond to a number of other cell types - will be elucidated . Using high-resolution confocal microscopy of fixed and living samples those aspects of actin cytoskeletal dynamics that are regulated by prostaglandins will be determined. The distinct, and likely opposing, roles of the two prostaglandins during cytoskeletal remodeling will then be determined. Furthermore, a screen will be performed to identify the actin binding proteins that mediate prostaglandin-dependent actin remodeling. The proteins utilized to directly mediate such remodeling are conserved from Drosophila to humans; therefore, the mechanistic insights resulting from the proposed work will be widely applicable. Thus, the Drosophila follicle maturation system is uniquely positioned to provide critical insights into conserved mechanisms by which two specific prostaglandins differentially regulate actin cytoskeletal remodeling.

Broader Impacts
This project will provide research and educational opportunities for students, and will lead to the development of novel tools and methodologies. Undergraduates from both the University of Iowa and other institutions will contribute in this research. Additionally, this project will provide Ph.D thesis projects for graduate students. The research will be presented by both the undergraduate and graduate students at the University's monthly Drosophila research meeting, which was started by the PI. The project will also contribute to graduate education through a Genetics course, where the PI teaches Drosophila genetic methods; a Cell Migration course, where the PI teaches Drosophila methods, image methods/analyses, and cell biology, and a Biochemistry course, where the PI teaches lipid biology and analysis techniques. The research will also lead to the development of new tools for imaging actin dynamics in vivo and quantitative methods of 3D and 4D image analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lipid signals called prostaglandins regulate the actin cytoskeleton, which controls cell division, shape, and migration; however, how this regulation occurs remains largely unknown. As the structure and function of actin are controlled by actin binding proteins, we hypothesized that prostaglandins regulate specific actin binding proteins to control the actin cytoskeleton. By taking advantage of the robust genetic model system of Drosophila and the well-characterized and actin-dependent process of oogenesis or follicle development, we have uncovered new mechanisms for how prostaglandins regulate the actin cytoskeleton. Specifically, prostaglandins coordinate actin remodeling with development; prostaglandins block premature actin filament formation at one stage of development, and in a later stage, prostaglandins promote filament formation. One way prostaglandins control when and where actin filaments form is by regulating the actin binding protein Enabled. Enabled promotes filament growth. Another way prostaglandins promote actin filament formation is by activating Fascin. Fascin bundles actin filaments together, giving them increased strength and rigidity. Through these studies, new means by which prostaglandins regulate the actin cytoskeleton have been uncovered.

 

We made the novel discovery that Fascin is not solely a cytoplasmic protein, but localizes and functions in the nucleus and at the nuclear periphery; PGs regulate Fascin at these cellular sites. We find that nuclear Fascin regulates the structure of the nucleolus; the nucleolus is considered the cell’s center for responding to stress. Perinuclear Fascin likely acts as part of a protein complex that is important for relaying mechanical force to the nucleus, and thus, allowing the cell to respond to its environment. Importantly, both the localization and function of Fascin in the nucleus and at the nuclear periphery are conserved from flies to humans. These studies transform the view of Fascin from being just an actin bundling protein to being a key regulator of nuclear activity and mechanotransduction.

 

Actin also is found in and functions within the nucleus; however, our understanding of nuclear actin is in its infancy. We find that expression of fluorescent probes that bind to and label the actin cytoskeleton induce nuclear actin filament formation during specific stages of follicle development. As these tools can stabilize actin, we hypothesized that nuclear actin was playing a role during these stages. Indeed, the nurse cells exhibit varying levels of endogenous nuclear actin during these same stages of development. We also find that Fascin regulates the cell-specific accumulation of nuclear actin by directly interacting with actin in the nucleus and by regulating a factor necessary for the localization of actin to the nucleus. These studies establish Drosophila oogenesis as the first multi-cellular, in vivo model to study the regulation and function of nuclear actin, and identify Fascin as a new regulator of nuclear actin.

 

Broader impacts: We take multiple approaches to increasing the diversity of people pursuing STEM education and careers. We host interactive lab tours for high schools students. Additionally, seminars on “why fruit flies are useful for biological research” are given to undergraduate and high school students. We have also developed a course based mini research experience for an undergraduate genetics course at minority-serving university to increase the number of students who are exposed to biological research. Notably, this experience utilized our video methods paper as a resource for the students. Finally, numerous undergraduate and high school students have been directly involved in the research described above.
